results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 6]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film, titled ‘Mountains of Mystery’, contains a trip around The Grampians National Park in Victoria. The filmmaker captures the various activities of visitors to the Grampians area as well as views across the mountains, an occasional bee, lizard, snake and echidna, trees, bush and wildflowers as well as the overall rocky terrain.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 titles ‘A Walkabout Film’, ‘Mountains of Mystery’ and ‘A WHC Film’
00:00:22:00 hikers on top of a huge log across a creek.
00:01:57:00 an echidna hiding in the bush.
00:02:05:00 hikers walking along a bush track.
00:07:20:00 instruction card for walkers and hikers.
00:07:55:00 sign to various locations in the Park.
00:08:06:00 hikers climbing up trails and narrow ravines among dramatic grey rocky outcrops followed by views from the summit.
00:09:57:00 a koala asleep in a tree
00:10:02:00 an intrepid hiker perched precariously on a high narrow rock ledge
00:10:39:00 plaque for ‘Makefing Reserve’ near the Grampians
00:11:00:00 signpost for ‘Makefing Rd’ (in two directions) and ‘Emmet Rd’ and ‘Stockyard…’ (which could be a sign to ‘Stockyard Hill’
00:11:19:00 park sign for ‘Major Mitchell Plateau’, ‘Mt William’, ‘Jimmy Creek’
00:12:29:00 hikers preparing a couple of ‘billy cans’ of tea and/or food on a small open fire
00:12:59:00 a hiker in all red gear including a woollen cap with a ‘pom pom’
00:13:45:00 scenes of hikers on steep tracks and then views from the summit
00:15:12:00 hikers gather around a boiling ‘billy’ on a small fire
00:15:40:00 sitting enjoying their tea
00:16:25:00 and echidna hiding in the grass
00:16:37:00 tree ferns followed by an old, plank footbridge over a creek
00:16:57:00 title card ‘The End’

results.title: Memories of a radio
results.creator_credit: Gordon Preston and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: Gordon Preston talks about his life, his love of the radio and the comfort it brings him. He shares key experiences from his life, like when he first arrived in Melbourne by ship and his vivid dreams and how his radio has followed him everywhere, sometimes illuminating the life he is missing out on, sometimes illuminating his memories and dreams.
results.description: Gordon Preston talks about his life, his love of the radio and the comfort it brings him. He shares key experiences from his life, like when he first arrived in Melbourne by ship and his vivid dreams and how his radio has followed him everywhere, sometimes illuminating the life he is missing out on, sometimes illuminating his memories and dreams.
description_for_label: Gordon Preston talks about his life, his love of the radio and the comfort it brings him. He shares key experiences from his life, like when he first arrived in Melbourne by ship and his vivid dreams and how his radio has followed him everywhere, sometimes illuminating the life he is missing out on, sometimes illuminating his memories and dreams.

results.title: Dear mother
results.creator_credit: Judith Mahfoud and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: Life wasn’t meant to be easy, but it still can be profoundly beautiful. Judith delves into the childhood of her mother, to try to understand her better so she can pass this knowledge to her five sons and to honour the life of her mother, who grew up feeling like she was nobody’s child.

results.title: Mind's eye
results.creator_credit: Brandon Tomlin and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: For years, I have been compiling images in my mind’s eye, while passing through the laneways of Richmond, to the neon lights of Melbourne. Despite having cerebral palsy, Brandon Tomlin lives independently and spends his time taking photos of Melbourne and surrounding suburbs. This is a compilation of some of his work.

results.title: Australia : the Land of my dreams = Kraj moich marzen
results.creator_credit: Mariola Gorna and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: Born in Poland, Mariola chose to come to Australia. After a long wait in Greece, she was finally granted the right to immigrate to Australia. She tells of the second family she found at Brintons carpet factory and how they were there for her during some of her most difficult times.
results.title_for_label: Australia : the Land of my dreams = Kraj moich marzen

results.title: Put back together
results.creator_credit: Clarissa Hall and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: I love angels. They are very peaceful. When I look at an angel sitting at home with all its scars, it reminds me of all the people who have guided me. Clarissa Hall gives an open account of her life, from leaving school early, to the degrading sheltered workshops and, eventually, to becoming a Big Issue vendor. She talks about her battle with mental illness and recovery and her hopes for her future.

She talks about her battle with mental illness and recovery and her hopes for her future.

results.title: My best mate
results.creator_credit: Aaron Austin and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: Huss was polite, generous and non-judgemental. Big Issue vendor, Aaron Austin paints a portrait of a man from the war-torn country of Somalia who, despite his violent upbringing, was kind to everyone who crossed his path. A soccer fan and storyteller, Huss was taken from Aaron when he was stabbed in the doorway of his flat in 2007.
results.description: Huss was polite, generous and non-judgemental. Big Issue vendor, Aaron Austin paints a portrait of a man from the war-torn country of Somalia who, despite his violent upbringing, was kind to everyone who crossed his path. A soccer fan and storyteller, Huss was taken from Aaron when he was stabbed in the doorway of his flat in 2007.
description_for_label: Huss was polite, generous and non-judgemental. A soccer fan and storyteller, Huss was taken from Aaron when he was stabbed in the doorway of his flat in 2007.

results.title: Long term employment
results.creator_credit: Michael Farquhar and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: Michael Farquhar walked into Brintons to leave his details at reception. The same day he had and interview and got a job. In his time there, he moved through many different areas and went through many life changes, from renting an appartment to marriage, owning a home and raising a family. When Brintons closed in 2008, Michael had worked there for 21 years. He talks about what it was like to work there, in the good and bad times.
results.description: Michael Farquhar walked into Brintons to leave his details at reception. The same day he had and interview and got a job. In his time there, he moved through many different areas and went through many life changes, from renting an appartment to marriage, owning a home and raising a family. When Brintons closed in 2008, Michael had worked there for 21 years. He talks about what it was like to work there, in the good and bad times.

results.title: Why did you leave such a beautiful place?
results.creator_credit: Margaret O'Connell and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: Margaret O’Connell tells of how she moved to be with her sister in Geelong, of her first days at Brintons carpet factory and how her loneliness was soon replaced by the family she made there. She join the Equal Opportunity and Consultative Committees and, when the factory closed in 2008, had been there for 32 years.

results.title: The Honeymoon
results.creator_credit: Laurel Whitcroft (Allen) and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: My family has a tradition of holidaying at Mt Buffalo Chalet, that has continued through four generations. A family album of the holidays in the Victorian Alps taken initially by Laurel and her husband for their honeymoon, then the subsequent returns by the growing family throughout the decades.
results.description: My family has a tradition of holidaying at Mt Buffalo Chalet, that has continued through four generations.
